node.description: Electric Engine is my new project. Different from electric motor because it retains a cylinder and a piston similar to solenoid engine but its design requires minimal current and voltage but produce noticeable torque. My aim is to have a renewable, sustainable, and affordable clean energy beginning on household and then to industrial application.

node.description:
My son (8 yrs) and I are making the Otto Humanoid as our first robot project working together. He's really excited about the expressiveness of the robot and that it uses our 3D printer which opens up customization options in the future.

Unfortunately, we've run into some stumbling blocks which are largely due to insufficient or incorrect instructions. Here's our list of questions/problems. I'd appreciate any help we can get clarifying or fixing them for ourselves and future builders.

Quick note: since I had 50% of the electronics already, we've sourced the remaining parts for the build. Some of these issues are fit issues which may be due to our sourced parts. A more helpful BOM with specifications for the parts would greatly help.

1. New Head is Different - Both the instructions and the how-to video use a prior version of the 3D printed head. Version 7 of the head (which we printed) has rotated the orientation for mounting most of the components. Please update the instructions and post a new video showing how to install using the new head.

2. Extra Screw Holes - The head has 6 total screw holes but only 4 are used for the nano. What are the other two screw holes used for? Our guess is the gyroscope, though the instructions and video show it taped.

3. What Screws? - Speaking of screws, the only screws which are shown in the BOM are the screws that come with the servos. However, we used all 18 screws for mounting the actual servos. What screws should we be using for mounting the nano and other mounting? How many do we need and what type?

4. Large Touch Sensor - Our touch sensor is 24mm x 24mm but the cut-out hole in the head is 14mm x 21mm (+/- 1mm). Do we need to source a different-sized touch sensor or will it work if we just tape it over that hole? What touch sensor should we use?

5. Bluetooth Module Mounting - I found in the comments for the YouTube making video that the bluetooth module is supposed to slide into the slot on the side of the head. Unfortunately, our module doesn't quite fit due to the slot being too narrow closest to the ultrasonic sensor. I'm going to try to file this down, but I wanted to call it out. It's also possible that this is support material. However, I haven't been able to dislodge it and it looks like it's integral to the part.

6. Sound Sensort Mounting - Placement for the sounds sensor is unclear. I couldn't identify it in the video nor is it covered in the manual. Where are we supposed to put it?

7. Incomplete Project BOM - The BOM for the project on this wiki site doesn't include all of the parts referenced in the manual. For example, it doesn't actually call out that a nano is needed, only a nano shield. Also I don't believe it calls out the bluetooth module.

8. LED Matrix Doesn't Fit - We purchased a MAX7219 based red LED matrix module. Unfortunately, like most of the ones available for purchase, it has the MAX7219 IC mounted on the PCB to the side of the LED matrix. This makes the unit longer and it runs into the ultrasonic sensor when we try to close the head. I'm trying to source a smaller unit with the IC behind the matrix. Considering how little space is available for all these components, I recommend adding some height to the head/body which would both give a little more room to work with and also could enable support for the more common, longer LED matrix. For reference, our PCB for the LED matrix is 32mm wide (perfect fit) by 50mm long (too long, hits ultrasonic sensor).

9. Leg Servo Screws - Neither the video or the instruction manual actually show where to put the third screw when screwing the feet into the legs. I worked it out, but the manual's picture is woefully unhelpful and the video doesn't show the screw going in to the motor to mount it to the leg piece. Please make this more clear for future builders.

That's all I've got for now. We're very excited (still) to be building our Otto and I'm looking forward to posting our success soon! Thanks for your help!
node.title: Multiple Issues With Building the Otto Humanoid (self-sourced)

node.description:
Dear Camilo

I am trying to upload [OttoHumanoid_V9_3f13bcd.ino](https://wikifactory.com/+OttoDIY/humanoid/v/3f13bcd/file/APP/OttoHumanoid_V9.ino) that make use of [OttoDIYLibV9_8665fff](https://wikifactory.com/+OttoDIY/humanoid/file/OttoDIYLibV9.zip) to the Arduno nano board. However, the following error appears. Any idea?

PS. I got the same error in Windows10x64 and Ubuntu18.04x64. . Also, I would say that `OttoHumanoid_V9` is not available in the current repository.

```

libraries/SoftwareSerial/SoftwareSerial.cpp.o (symbol from plugin): In function `SoftwareSerial::read()':

(.text+0x0): multiple definition of `__vector_3'

sketch/OttoHumanoid_V9_3f13bcd.ino.cpp.o (symbol from plugin):(.text+0x0): first defined here

libraries/SoftwareSerial/SoftwareSerial.cpp.o (symbol from plugin): In function `SoftwareSerial::read()':

(.text+0x0): multiple definition of `__vector_4'

sketch/OttoHumanoid_V9_3f13bcd.ino.cpp.o (symbol from plugin):(.text+0x0): first defined here

libraries/SoftwareSerial/SoftwareSerial.cpp.o (symbol from plugin): In function `SoftwareSerial::read()':

(.text+0x0): multiple definition of `__vector_5'

sketch/OttoHumanoid_V9_3f13bcd.ino.cpp.o (symbol from plugin):(.text+0x0): first defined here

collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

exit status 1

Error compiling for board Arduino Nano.

```
node.title: Error compiling for board Arduino Nano: (.text+0x0): multiple definition of `__vector_3'

node.description:
Hello, thank you for sharing your Otto creation! I see you have added the files and information appropriate for creating this project. I noticed in the ReadMe you have one large section. I recommend that you create sections, or subheadings, in order to break this up. Generally, sections allow you to better categorise and organise your project's information.

Sections in the ReadMe (found on the left-hand side of the ReadMe) help users to better navigate the project. For example, you can create the following sections: "Background Information"; "Project Inspiration"; "Materials"; "Assembly Protocol"; and "Licence."

By adding sections to the ReadMe, you would greatly enhance your project's profile. If you have any questions, please let me know. Best, Emily
node.title: Add sections to ReadMe
